page.title: Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1:
{{Userspace draft|source=ArticleWizard|date=May 2011}}
{{Userspace draft|source=ArticleWizard|date=May 2011}}
'''[[Human rights]] in the [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concerns and controversies since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF)''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}''have been accused of [[Human rights in Egypt|human rights]] [[Human rights violations|violations]]. The SCAF, which consists of a body of 20<ref name=sis>{{cite web| url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/LastPage.aspx?Category_ID=1136| author=Egypt State Information Service| title=Formation of the Armed Forces Supreme Council.| date=February 14, 2011}} Archived at webcite at http://www.webcitation.org/5wTMNq7Mb</ref> senior officers in the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], was handed the power to govern [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on February 11, 2011<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name=wt>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the 2011 Egyptian revolution.
'''[[Human rights]] in the [[Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|post-Mubarak transition]]''' have been the subject of concerns and controversies since the [[2011 Egyptian revolution]]. The '''[[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]] (SCAF)''' ({{lang-ar|Ø§ÙÙØ¬ÙØ³ Ø§ÙØ£Ø¹ÙÙ ÙÙÙÙØ§Øª Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­Ø©}}, ''{{transl|ar|DIN|al-MaÇ§lis al-Ê¾AÊ¿lÄ lil-QuwwÄt al-Musallaá¸¥ah}}''have been accused of [[Human rights in Egypt|human rights]] [[Human rights violations|violations]]. The SCAF, which consists of a body of 20<ref name=sis>{{cite web| url=http://www.sis.gov.eg/En/LastPage.aspx?Category_ID=1136| author=Egypt State Information Service| title=Formation of the Armed Forces Supreme Council.| date=February 14, 2011}} Archived at webcite at http://www.webcitation.org/5wTMNq7Mb</ref> senior officers in the [[Egyptian Armed Forces|Egyptian military]], was handed the power to govern [[Egypt]] after the ouster of [[President of Egypt|President]] [[Hosni Mubarak]] on February 11, 2011<ref name=globe>{{cite news |url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/the-new-face-of-power-in-cairo/article1904700/ |author=The Globe and Mail |title=The New Face of Power in Egypt. |date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref><ref name=wt>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/feb/11/crowds-rejoice-egypts-mubarak-steps-down/ |author=Murdock, Heather |title=Crowds rejoice as Egyptâs Mubarak steps down, hands power to military| publisher=[[The Washington Times]]| date=February 11, 2011| accessdate=February 11, 2011}}</ref> as a consequence of the 2011 Egyptian revolution.
  +   +
==Censorship of Free Speech==
  +
[[File:Ganzeer.jpg|thumb|Mohammed Fahmy AKA Ganzeer]]
  +   +
Egyptian blogger and activist [[Hossam el-Hamalawy]], television host [[Reem Maged]] and journalist [[Nabil Sharaf El-Din]] were given a summons on Monday the 30th of May, 2011 to appear before military prosecution after Maged brought Hamalawy on her show where he criticized the role of military police, holding the head of the military police responsible for torturing activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/1/64/13270/Egypt/Politics-/Egyptian-journalists-to-be-questioned-tomorrow-by-.aspx |title=Egyptian journalists to be questioned tomorrow by military for denouncing the torture of activists - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-05-30}}</ref> They were released Tuesday after "chatting" with Military Prosecution and Hossam el-Hamalawy was asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities<ref name="DailyEgypt">{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/blogger-asked-to-hand-reports-of-army-abuses-to-authorities.html |title=Blogger asked to hand reports of army abuses to authorities |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-07}}</ref>
  +   +
Mohammed Fahmy also Known as Ganzeer<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Middle-East/2011/0526/Egyptian-graffiti-artist-Ganzeer-arrested-amid-surge-in-political-expression |title=Egyptian graffiti artist Ganzeer arrested amid surge in political expression |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/~/NewsContent/5/35/13024/Arts--Culture/Stage--Street/CIC-condemns-arrest-of-artists-by-military-.aspx |title=CIC condemns arrest of artists by military - Stage & Street - Arts & Culture - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedailynewsegypt.com/human-a-civil-rights/graffiti-artist-says-online-outcry-may-have-sped-up-release.html |title=Graffiti artist says online outcry may have sped up release |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref>
  +
<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/05/26/egypts-youth-vocal-against-army |title=Egypt's youth vocal against army | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date=2011-05-26 |accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Shenker in Cairo |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/may/19/egypts-uprising-diy-art-cairo-streets |title=Egypt's uprising brings DIY spirit out on to the streets | World news |publisher=The Guardian |date= |accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=New York Times, USA |url=http://globalvoicesonline.org/2011/05/27/egypt-gearing-up-for-a-second-revolutionary-round/ |title=Egypt: Gearing Up for a Second Revolutionary Round Â· Global Voices |publisher=Globalvoicesonline.org |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2011-06-13}}</ref>.
  +   +
==Murder==
  +
{{empty section}}
==Military Trials==
==Military Trials==
Line 12: Line 23:
[[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]]
[[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]]
Ramy Essam, the 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on the 9th of March, 2011<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2011-03-18 |accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref>. Without warning, the army stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents and arresting more than 100 people, including Ramy Essam<ref name="NPR"/>. He says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters<ref name="NPR"/>. He says the men took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing Ramy Essam<ref name="NPR"/>. "They took off my clothes. They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He received electric shocks, he said<ref name="CNN"/>. "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs"<ref name="CNN"/>. Ramy Essam is best known as the singer of the Egyptian revolution dur to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=2011-03-15 |accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref>.
Ramy Essam, the 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on the 9th of March, 2011<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2011-03-18 |accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref>. Without warning, the army stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents and arresting more than 100 people, including Ramy Essam<ref name="NPR"/>. He says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters<ref name="NPR"/>. He says the men took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing Ramy Essam<ref name="NPR"/>. "They took off my clothes. They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He received electric shocks, he said<ref name="CNN"/>. "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs"<ref name="CNN"/>. Ramy Essam is best known as the singer of the Egyptian revolution dur to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=2011-03-15 |accessdate=2011-06-10}}</ref>.
